Problem:
Consider the behavior of a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions of time t that satisfy a coupled differential equation system \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + By \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = Cx + Dy \\), with constants A, B, C, and D. We investigate how the Fourier transform of \\( z(t) \\), defined as \\( Z(\\omega) = \\mathcal{F}\\{z(t)\\} \\), impacts causal inference.

If at some point \\( t_1 \\), the system is modified with an intervention via matrix operation \\( M \\) to the state function, will the Fourier transform \\( Z'(\\omega) \\) at time \\( T > t_1 \\) depend only on the original matrix coefficients A, B, C, and D?
Explanation: The intervention with matrix \\( M \\) changes the state directions or magnitudes, directly affecting both \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) and hence \\( z(t) \\). Consequently, the Fourier transform \\( Z'(\\omega) \\) will reflect the impact of M in addition to A, B, C, and D.
